canvases.label: Romeo and Juliet, 1599, Inside front cover & front end paper recto

metadata.value: Inside front cover & front end paper recto
metadata.label: Subset Index

metadata.value: View of pages from a quarto of Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet. Published in 1599 by T. Creede of London, this volume is one of the earliest examples of Shakespearean literature, as it dates to well within the author's own lifetime (Romeo and Juliet itself is believed to have been written between 1591 and 1595). It was donated to Edinburgh University between 1626 and 1636 by former student William Drummond, making it part of the university's first literature collection. Sources: http://www.shakespeare-online.com/playanalysis/romeoplayhistory.html (accessed 24/09/14). http://www.ed.ac.uk/schools-departments/information-services/library-museum-gallery/crc/collections/special-collections/rare-books-and-manuscripts/rare-books-directory-section/william-drummond (accessed 24/09/14). http://www.quartos.org/index.html (accessed 24/09/14).
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Romeo and Juliet, 1599, Inside front cover & front end paper recto
metadata.label: Repro Title

canvases.label: Romeo and Juliet, 1599, Front end paper verso & f.fl.1r

metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Title page from the second 'good' quarto printed in 1599. The first quarto printed in 1597 is considered 'bad' and the second printing contains half again as much text as its predecessor. The second quarto was printed by Thomas Creede for Cuthbert Burby, and was 'newly corrected, augmented, and amended' likely from Shakespeare's foul papers. The title page of this book bears a shelfmark and signature reading M. Drummond, as well as three shelfmarks that have since been crossed out. This copy of the second quarto was given to the University in 1627 by William Drummond (1585-1649) of Hawthornden, a former student, poet, and man of letters. The quarto is now bound in green morocco with the University of Edinburgh arms on the front and back, and the bookplate on the front pastedown.
metadata.label: Description

Sources: http://www.shakespeare-online.com/playanalysis/romeoplayhistory.html (accessed 24/09/14). http://www.ed.ac.uk/schools-departments/information-services/library-museum-gallery/crc/collections/special-collections/rare-books-and-manuscripts/rare-books-directory-section/william-drummond (accessed 24/09/14). http://www.quartos.org/index.html (accessed 24/09/14).
